channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israeli Leader Says He Feels No Pressure to Quit Bombing Gaza
item.description: Deadly Israeli airstrikes and persistent Palestinian rocket attacks indicate the two sides are set on a course of further escalation.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER, FARES AKRAM and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike Friday in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: For Gazans, a Tense and Somber Ramadan
item.description: Airstrikes have stirred anxiety, but beyond the conflict Gazans face economic stress as well, making this Ramadan a difficult one.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Palestinians in Gaza City at the scene of an Israeli airstrike on Friday.

item.title: In Congo, Salaam Kivu Festival Brings Performers to Goma
item.description: Memories of better days inspire the founders of an arts festival in a city in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: A dancer performs during a competition at the Salaam Kivu International Film Festival.

item.title: Kerry Pushes for Solution to Afghanistan Election Crisis
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Afghanistan to help settle a dispute between the two candidates that puts the viability of the government at stake.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry greets the Afghanistan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah at the American embassy in Kabul on Friday.

item.title: News Analysis: For Israelis and Palestinians, Separation Is Dehumanizing
item.description: Israelis and Palestinians once worked and socialized together. Increasing separation has made them strangers who distrust and fear each other.
item.dc:creator: By ETHAN BRONNER
item.media:description: The Israeli security barrier cuts through the Palestinian town of Abu Dis in the West Bank.

item.title: Lens Blog: Soccer in Brazil, and Outside the World’s Glare
item.description: Mauricio Lima went to remote villages, up the river and even to a prison, to document his countrymen’s passion for the sport, as well as their lives, during the World Cup.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers on the third deck of the boat PP Maués during a 15-hour overnight trip down the Amazon River from Manaus to Maués.

item.title: Palestinian Death Toll Nears 100 in Gaza, W.H.O. Warns of Health Emergency
item.description: Deadly Israeli airstrikes and persistent Palestinian rocket attacks indicate the two sides are set on a course of further escalation.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER, FARES AKRAM and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike Friday in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Rift With Kurds Widens as Iraqi Leader Ousts Foreign Minister
item.description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s decision to replace Hoshyar Zebari, the Kurdish foreign minister, came as Kurds seized two oil production facilities in Kirkuk Province.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: The replacement of Hoshyar Zebari as foreign minister of Iraq infuriated the Kurds.

item.title: Seeing Cost of Saber Rattling in Ukraine, Putin Alters Course
item.description: Analysts say that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is angling to keep Ukraine as weak and decentralized as possible as he restores ties with the West.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexey Nikolsky/Ria Novosti/Kremlin
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, was greeted Friday in Cuba, where is he on an official visit.

item.title: 30 Reported Dead After Separatist Rockets Hit Ukraine Military Camp
item.description: Rebels in the east of the country reportedly used a Russian-made artillery system to attack Ukrainian soldiers and border guards.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Pro-Russian militants drive past a checkpoint near Donetsk, Ukraine, on Friday. Intense battles raged Friday around Donetsk's international airport.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Voting in China, a Distant Dream
item.description: Never in my life have I seen a ballot to elect the delegates who meet every year in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By YU HUA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Open a Nuclear Fuel Bank
item.description: An international facility to ensure access to supplies could help support and reinforce an agreement with Iran.
item.dc:creator: By SAM NUNN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Guangxi Officials Told to Stay Sober (on the Job, at Least)
item.description: Officials in the southern Chinese region of Guangxi have been issued a list of rules meant to prevent them from reaching embarrassing levels of intoxication.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: China has a well-known tradition of heavy drinking at official banquets.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, Super Boys Learn to Say, ‘I Am Myself’
item.description: “Super Boy” has inspired a documentary that goes behind the scenes at the “American Idol”-style TV talent show to explore the psyche and rites of passage of a group of young Chinese men.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Finalists belting out songs on the popular Chinese TV talent show "Super Boy," the subject of a new documentary.

item.title: Fleeing Gangs, Children Head to U.S. Border
item.description: An increase in gang-related killings of children is a key factor driving the surge of migration of young Central Americans to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clothes were laid out in remembrance of Kenneth Castellanos, 7, who was tortured and killed in his Honduran neighborhood.

item.title: Science Journal Pulls 60 Papers in Peer-Review Fraud
item.description: A researcher in Taiwan was accused of creating online accounts to judge his own academic papers in the journal called a “peer-review and citation ring.”
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Open Source: Rumor and Leaks Fill a Void as Israel Silences Press Over Killings
item.description: Israeli officials used gag orders in recent weeks to stifle reporting on two investigations into the abduction and murder of four teenagers.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Pakistan Claims Win Against Militants Along Afghan Border, but Enemy Slips Away
item.description: Ten days after Pakistani troops moved into Miram Shah in an offensive against a main jihadi hub, many of the militants that had been hiding there had escaped.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pakistani soldiers patrolling a bazaar in Miram Shah. Many militants have evaded capture, blending with roughly 800,000 fleeing refugees.

item.title: Killing of Palestinian Youth Puts an Israeli Focus on Extremism
item.description: Some are observing a generational shift as Jewish youth in Israel express a distinct anti-Arab attitude that was not learned in the home.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Relatives at the funeral of eight Palestinians who medics said were killed in an early morning airstrike in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Kerry to Join Talks on Iran as Deadline Draws Near
item.description: The Obama administration said that Secretary of State John Kerry would fly to Vienna to assess whether a deal is possible in talks on Iran’s nuclear activities.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Editorial Observer: Once Again, Art in Russia Carries Moral and Political Overtones
item.description: Exhibits provide a counterpoint to President Vladimir Putin’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Kurdish Talks Bolstered
item.description: Lawmakers on Thursday approved a legal framework to advance peace talks with Kurdish militants aimed at ending a three-decade insurgency.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: World Cup Soccer Fans Seek Asylum
item.description: At least 200 people from Ghana who entered Brazil as tourists to watch World Cup games have asked for asylum, a police official said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: Opposition Under Fire
item.description: The government charged two leaders of Bahrain’s largest opposition group with illegally meeting an American official.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: World Briefing: New Envoy for Syria Appointed
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced Thursday that he had appointed Staffan de Mistura, a veteran diplomat of Italian-Swedish heritage, to be the new special envoy responsible for seeking an end to the conflict in Syria.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
